body:
cc @rockg

can you take a look?

Testing:

```
def next_monday(t):
    return t + pd.DateOffset(weekday=0)

tz = "US/Pacific"
def test_week_start():    
    # a Tuesday - should return next week
    t = next_monday(pd.Timestamp("2013-01-01", tz=tz))
    assert(t.hour == 0 and t.dayofweek == 0 and t.day == 7)

    # a Monday - should return same day
    t = next_monday(pd.Timestamp("2013-01-07", tz=tz))
    assert(t.hour == 0 and t.dayofweek == 0 and t.day == 7)

     # fall back is Sun. Nov 03
    t = next_monday(pd.Timestamp("2013-10-30", tz=tz))
    assert(t.hour == 0 and t.dayofweek == 0)

    # spring fwd is Sun. Mar 10
    t = next_monday(pd.Timestamp("2013-03-08", tz=tz))
    assert(t.hour == 0  and t.dayofweek == 0)
```

see the last part of this section: http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/timeseries.html#timeseries-timezone

there is a new kw, `infer_dst` that you can set in localize to 'fix' this problem; might need to be enabled here somehow

Also, there is a bug in dateutil (the default for DateOffset) which does not take into account tz when going from a dst to non-dst time. I don't know if we want to fix it there or account for it in DateOffset (the easiest fix is to remove the tzinfo, apply the offset, and then reapply the tzinfo).

@adamgreenhall @jreback This is what I'm talking about.  The issue is that the tzinfo remains the same offset despite the dst offset actually changing.  So tzinfo needs to be removed, the offset applied, and then the result needs to be localized using the initial tzinfo.  This should probably be implemented in DateOffset for everything.

```
>>> ts = pd.Timestamp('2013-03-08', tz='US/Pacific')
>>> ts
Timestamp('2013-03-08 00:00:00-0800', tz='US/Pacific')
>>> tzinfo = ts.tzinfo
>>> ts = ts.replace(tzinfo=None)
>>> ts + pd.DateOffset(weekday=0)
Timestamp('2013-03-11 00:00:00', tz=None)
>>> ts = ts + pd.DateOffset(weekday=0)
>>> newts = tzinfo.localize(ts)
>>> pd.Timestamp(newts)
Timestamp('2013-03-11 00:00:00-0700', tz='US/Pacific')
```
@rockg is this true ONLY for a dst transition? (eg. should it always be done)?

@jreback Ideally only for offsets that span dst transitions, but I don't know how that will be known ahead of time (or at least in an efficient manner as you would basically need to do the operation twice). Localizing and unlocalizing are optimized for DatetimeIndex so I think doing it always makes sense in that case, but there will be some new plumbing.  This will only fix his last two test cases.
ok....will put you down for this! if you want to try for 0.13 ok....but would need by next week
Okay. I probably won't get to it seriously until early next week so probably not for the release, but shortly after.
gr8

Actually I'm not sure about this solution method. It fails in the case where we are just adding hours over a DST transition:

```
def test_hours_add_fall_back():
    # fall back adds an extra hour. so 10pm + 8hrs should be 5am
    t = pd.Timestamp("2013-11-03 22:00", tz=tz) + pd.DateOffset(hours=8)
    assert(t.hour == 5)


def test_hours_add_spring_forward():
    # spring forward looses an hour. so 10pm + 8hrs should be 7am
    t = pd.Timestamp("2013-03-01 22:00", tz=tz) + pd.DateOffset(hours=8)
    assert(t.hour == 7)
```

@rockg thoughts?
I think your first test case is supposed to be 2013-11-02 22:00 since 11/3 is the transition day so you aren't straddling the DST day.  Same with your second case (should be 2013-03-02).

@adamgreenhall also you can't replace.  You need to localize the resulting timestamp.  Replacing does not force any recalculation of the offset.  One thing about this approach is that we I don't know if we can be assured that tzinfo will have the localize method.  Only those tzs created from pytz will have that I believe.  I know the that is the default in pandas, but we might want to throw an error or something when a tzinfo without localize is present.
Sorry, spring date should be 2013-03-9.

You are right.  This approach does not seem to work when looking at sub-daily offsets.  I believe it's because of the **radd** in relativedelta.  The year, month, days are replaced whereas sub-daily uses timedeltas which do not need to be localized.

```
        repl = {"year": year, "month": month, "day": day}
...
        ret = (other.replace(**repl)
               + datetime.timedelta(days=days,
                                    hours=self.hours,
                                    minutes=self.minutes,
                                    seconds=self.seconds,
                                    microseconds=self.microseconds))
```

Yes - not working for sure:

```
# fall back adds an extra hour. so 10pm + 8hrs should be 5am
In [18]: Timestamp("2013-11-02 22:00", tz='US/Pacific') + DateOffset(hours=8)
Out[18]: Timestamp('2013-11-03 06:00:00-0800', tz='US/Pacific')    
```

Also added some tests to make sure that the offset is changing properly. 

What do you think about strategy to fix?

Weekday uses the timedelta days offset.  To me, adding a day should return the same hour value.  However, hours/minutes/seconds/microseconds/... seem to work okay.  We need to differentiate the path based on the type of offset.

```
ts
Timestamp('2013-11-02 22:00:00-0400', tz='US/Eastern')
ts + datetime.timedelta(hours=8)
Timestamp('2013-11-03 05:00:00-0500', tz='US/Eastern')
ts + datetime.timedelta(days=1)
Timestamp('2013-11-03 21:00:00-0500', tz='US/Eastern')
```
I don't know if anything needs to be done in Tick.  (Day is derived from Tick).
`Tick` is a singular call - like `day` or `month`, as opposed to `days` or `months`?
Tick is a DateOffset subclass geared more towards smaller time increments.  I think only Day would require any logic but since Tick is a DateOffset, maybe your code will just work.
Got it. I didn't modify `Day`, but the tests seem to be passing - let's see what Travis says...

The build passes on my machine, but fails on 1 of 5 Travis jobs. I'm not exactly sure what the difference in setup is and how to track down how that difference contributes to the test failure. Could someone point me in the right direction?
Thanks @jreback. Didn't know the part about missing `total_seconds` in 2.6. This one should work.

@adamgreenhall I would add a couple more tests to test the Tick stuff we were talking about (maybe there are already tests in the suite, but I don't think so).  For example, Timestamp + Day(1) over the DST transition, Timestamp + Hour(24), and maybe a couple of the smaller ones.

@rockg - you're right - that does fail. 

```
class TestDST(unittest.TestCase):
    ts_pre_fallback = Timestamp("2013-11-02 22:00", tz='US/Pacific')
    ts_pre_springfwd = Timestamp("2013-03-09 22:00", tz='US/Pacific')

def test_day_add_fall_back(self):
    # adding Day() should result in same hour
    t = self.ts_pre_fallback + Day(1)
    assert(t.hour == 22 and get_utc_offset_hours(t) == -8)
```

fails with Timestamp('2013-11-03 21:00:00-0800', tz='US/Pacific').

`Hour` passes though. We do need to modify tick.

Took a look at modifying tick to make `Day` addition across DST result in the same hour. But I couldn't figure out where the addition is being called - the trace seems to skip `apply` go straight to `Tick.delta`:

```
In [2]: from pandas.tseries.offsets import Day

In [3]: from pandas import Timestamp

In [4]: ts_pre_fallback = Timestamp("2013-11-02 22:00", tz='US/Pacific')

In [7]: day = Day(1)

In [8]: %prun ts_pre_fallback + day
         4 function calls in 0.000 seconds

   Ordered by: internal time

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        1    0.000    0.000    0.000    0.000 <string>:1(<module>)
        2    0.000    0.000    0.000    0.000 offsets.py:1193(delta)
        1    0.000    0.000    0.000    0.000 {method 'disable' of '_lsprof.Profiler' objects}
```

What's going on here? Does this have to do with the `CacheableOffset` inheritance?

Is tick actually cacheable? That's surprising to me.

That said, it shouldn't affect this, all an offset does is change a date, it doesn't hold any particularly point in time. (i.e., `3 * Day() + <some timestamp>`)
`Tick` isn't, but `Day` is (the only one to inherit from `CacheableOffset` and `Tick`).
still I doubt it matters.

I tried pulling it out. No difference. Still a mystery as to where the
addition is happening.

On Wed, Oct 23, 2013 at 4:06 PM, Jeff Tratner notifications@github.comwrote:
